snippet: The Republican-controlled House overrode a veto to enact a law allowing court officials with a “sincerely held religious objection” to opt out of performing same-sex marriages.
abstract: North Carolina lawmakers vote 69-41 to override veto of Gov Pat McCrory and enact law that allows court officials to refuse to perform marriages on the basis of religious belief; law follows passage of similar bills in Indiana, Arkansas and Louisiana, and comes amid rise of sharply conservative moves by state's Republican-controlled legislature.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-controlled House overrode a veto to enact a law allowing court officials with a “sincerely held religious objection” to opt out of performing same-sex marriages.

headline.main: North Carolina Allows Officials to Refuse to Perform Gay Marriages
headline.print_headline: North Carolina Officials Can Now Cite Religion as Basis to Refuse Marriage Duties
